questions.suggested_answer: Factor: (x-5)(x-2). Zeroes: 5 and 2. Sum = 7 (= -b/a). Product = 10 (= c/a).

questions.question_text: Prove that √3 is an irrational number.
questions.suggested_answer: Assume √3 = p/q in lowest terms. Then p^2 = 3q^2 → 3 divides p → p=3k → 9k^2 = 3q^2 → q^2 = 3k^2 so 3 divides q as well. Contradiction. Hence √3 is irrational.

questions.suggested_answer: Quotient Q(x) = 2x^2 + x + 2, R(x) = 7x - 1. Verify by expanding (divisor×quotient)+remainder = dividend.

questions.question_text: A fruit seller sold 120 fruits consisting of apples at ₹6 each and oranges at ₹4 each and received ₹620. How many apples and oranges did he sell? Form pair of linear equations and solve. Verify your answer.
questions.chapter: Pair of Linear Equations in Two Variables
questions.suggested_answer: Let apples = x, oranges = y. x + y = 120; 6x + 4y = 620. Solve → x = 70, y = 50. Verification: 70×6 + 50×4 = 420 + 200 = 620.

For which values of p and q does the following pair of linear equations have (i) a unique solution, (ii) no solution, and (iii) infinitely many solutions? Give reasons. 4x + 5y = 12; px + 5y = q.
questions.chapter: Pair of Linear Equations in Two Variables
questions.suggested_answer: Use ratio test. Unique solution if p ≠ 4. No solution if p = 4 and q ≠ 12. Infinitely many solutions if p = 4 and q = 12. (Reason: compare ratios a1/a2, b1/b2, c1/c2)
